p: The second species, the Large Copper L. dispar (Haworth, 1802), is a transpalaearctic butterfly, ranging from western Europe across temperate Asia to the Amur region and Korea (Ebert & Rennwald, 1991; Settele et al., 2008). The species has 1–2 generations per year (Lindman et al., 2015; Settele et al., 2008) and typically occurs in wetland habitats including lakeside and riverside areas (Lindman et al., 2015; Settele et al., 2008). Eggs are laid on nonacidic sorrels (e.g., Rumex hydrolapathum Huds., R. crispus L., R. obtusifolius L.; Lindman et al., 2015 and references therein). Lycaena dispar is listed in the EU Habitat Directive and is considered vulnerable in the Red List of Germany (Binot‐Hafke et al., 2011; Martin, Van Dyck, Dendoncker, & Titeux, 2013; Settele et al., 2008). Because of its association with wetland habitats and declines in some parts of its range, we assess the species’ vulnerability to climate change as being intermediate. Mated females were caught in two univoltine populations in July 2013 in Estonia, vicinity of Liispõllu ( N = 9; N:58°15′; E:27°15′), and in Germany, vicinity of Anklam ( N = 20; N:53°53′; E:13°42′), and were transferred to Greifswald University for egg‐laying. Butterflies were kept for egg‐laying as outlined above, using R. hydrolapathum as oviposition substrate.
